questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the clinic with weakness in the thumb and difficulty gripping objects. On examination, the patient exhibits a loss of opposition of the thumb, as well as atrophy of the thenar eminence. Which of the following muscles is primarily supplied by the median nerve and is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flexor Pollicis Brevis

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case thumb/thenar muscles are involved which are supplied by median nerve (except Grave yard of ulnar nerve i.e.- adductor pollicis which is supplied by ulnar nerve.)
  • Among given options only Flexor pollicis brevis is thenar muscle hence it is the answer.
  • 4 Thenar Muscles shown in image:

 

 

  • 4 Hypothenar Muscles shown in image:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palmaris brevis is innervated by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. All dorsal interossei are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexor pollicis brevis, Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, first and second lumbricals in the hand are innervated by the median nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 166

questions.text: All of the following muscles have dual nerve supply except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pronator Teres

 

Option C:

 

  • Any muscle with double nerve supply known as Hybrid / Composite muscle
  • Pronator teres is innervated by the median nerve only.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Subscapularis is innervated by the upper and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option B. Pectoralis major is innervated by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves.

 

Option D. FDP tendon for medial ½ is innervated by the ulnar nerve and FDP tendon lateral ½ is  innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pronator teres muscle, helps to pronate the forearm and receives its nerve supply from the median nerve.
  • The median nerve originates from the brachial plexus, specifically from the lateral and medial cords and travels down the arm and into the forearm, it innervates several muscles, including the pronator teres.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty pointing their index finger. On examination, it is noted that the patient has weakness in flexing the index finger at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, while the other fingers remain unaffected. Which nerve is most likely to be affected in this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median Nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • In this case patient has weakness in flexing the only the index finger at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint is indicating the positive pointing index sign, which is seen in case of median nerve damage.

 

 

  • Median nerve injury at mid forearm causes paralysis of Flexor digitorum profundus (lateral ½) innervated by anterior interosseous nerve, branch of median nerve. Due to lesion at mid forearm mainly index finger muscle fibres are affected. Hence index finger can’t be flexed.
  • Medial ½ of FDP supplied by ulnar nerve. Hence 3 & 4 fingers can be easily flexed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve injury will result in claw hands.

 

 

Option C. Radial nerve injury results in wrist drop.

 

 

Option D. Injury to musculocutaneous nerve results in inability to flex elbow joint (brachialis, biceps brachii paralysis) and loss of cutaneous sensation over lateral aspect of forearm (Lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inability to flex the distal phalanx of index finger is called pointing index which occurs due to paralysis of Flexor digitorum profundus innervated by anterior interosseous nerve, branch of median nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 165

Opposition of thumb is produced by opponens pollicis that is innervated by median nerve

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was trying to pour water from a glass jar into his cup but the glass jar slipped off his fingers and fell down. As he tried to gather the broken pieces of glass, he noticed that one of those glass pieces deeply pierced the skin on the front of his right wrist. On examination, a small wound was present in the front of his forearm and the palmaris longus tendon had been severed. The thumb was laterally rotated and adducted, and the boy was unable to oppose his thumb to the other fingers. There was loss of skin sensation over the lateral half of the palm and the palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers.The following facts concerning this patient are correct except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The median nerve lies in the interval between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus just proximal to the wrist joint

 

Option C:

 

  • In the front of the forearm, close to the wrist, the median nerve can be found between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor carpi radialis.
  • Just proximal to the wrist joint, the median nerve is actually located more medially, typically lying just lateral to the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis and under the flexor retinaculum. The palmaris longus, when present, tends to be more superficial and median to the median nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The adductor pollicis muscle is indeed responsible for the adduction of the thumb, and it is innervated by the ulnar nerve. This aligns with the clinical presentation if the ulnar nerve is affected.

 

Option B. The opponens pollicis muscle, which facilitates the opposition of the thumb, is innervated by the median nerve. Loss of opposition ability in the thumb suggests median nerve injury.

 

Option D. The median nerve provides sensory innervation to the palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Median Nerve Lies in the Interval between the Tendons of Flexor Digitorum Superficialis and the Palmaris Longus Just Proximal to the Wrist Joint: The median nerve does not lie between the tendons of the flexor digitorum superficialis and the palmaris longus.
  • Just proximal to the wrist joint, the median nerve is actually located more medially, typically lying just lateral to the tendon of the flexor carpi radialis and under the flexor retinaculum. The palmaris longus, when present, tends to be more superficial and median to the median nerve.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg. 891
